title: Cardinals player streams manager Mike Shildt's expletive-filled postgame speech
text:
CLOSE USA TODAY Sports' Steve Gardner breaks down how the Cardinals were able to advance to the NLCS. USA TODAY Sports

The celebration was about to go down in the visitors' locker room at SunTrust Park in Atlanta, where the St. Louis Cardinals had bombarded the Braves with a historic 10-run first inning that set up a 13-1 beatdown in Game 5 of the NLDS.

But what Cardinals manager Mike Shildt didn't know was that there was a camera rolling in the room and that he was being broadcast to thousands on Instagram.

On the verge of popping bottles, St. Louis rookie Randy Arozarena began an Instagram Live and caught his skipper's expletive-filled congratulatory speech, according to ESPN.

"The (Braves) started some (expletive). We finished the (expletive)," Shildt said in the video. "And that's how we roll. No one (expletive) with us ever. Now, I don't give a (expletive) who we play. We're gonna (expletive) them up. We're gonna take it right to them the whole (expletive) way. We're gonna kick their (expletive) ass."

St. Louis Cardinals manager Mike Shildt speaks during the postgame press conference after Game 5 of the 2019 NLDS. (Photo: Dale Zanine, USA TODAY Sports)

Azorena deleted the stream and later apologized for posting what was supposed to be a private moment.

"I want to apologize to my teammates, manager, the Cardinals organization and baseball fans for the video I posted tonight after our victory in Atlanta," Arozarena said in a statement. "It was a moment meant to be private. I made a rookie mistake by sharing it on my social media account."

Although it's unknown what Shildt is referring to in the beginning of the clip, there was some bad blood between the Braves and Cardinals during the intense series. Cardinals pitcher Carlos Martinez and Braves phenom Ronald Acuña Jr. beefed over hot-dogging and pitching inside, and St. Louis right-hander Ryan Helsley — a member of the Cherokee Nation — took offense to the Atlanta crowd's tradition of doing the "tomahawk chop."

The Cardinals will take on the Washington Nationals in the NLCS, which begins Friday in St. Louis.
description: St. Louis Cardinals manager Mike Shildt had his expletive-filled postgame speech after his team won Game 5 of the NLDS livestreamed by a player.
